questions.text: A three-year-old child is brought to the emergency department having just ingested a large overdose of an antihistaminic drug. options.label: C

questions.text: Which of the following routes of administration is most suitable for drugs that are not well absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract?
What does the term 'bioavailability' refer to?

options.label: A
options.text: The fraction of an administered dose of a drug that reaches the systemic circulation

options.label: B
options.text: The degree to which a drug binds to plasma proteins

options.label: C
options.text: The rate at which a drug is metabolized by the liver

options.label: D
options.text: The speed at which a drug is excreted from the body

questions.correct_answer: A. The fraction of an administered dose of a drug that reaches the systemic circulation

questions.text: Which of the following interactions could potentially lead to an increased risk of bleeding?
What effect might a high-fat meal have on the absorption of certain oral medications?
Which adverse effect is associated with long-term use of corticosteroids?
Which type of drug interaction occurs when one drug alters the metabolism of another drug in the liver?
Which of the following drugs is an example of a competitive antagonist?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (C) Diazepam – Diazepam is a benzodiazepine agonist that binds to GABA-A receptors, enhancing the inhibitory effects of GABA and producing sedation, muscle relaxation, and anxiolysis. It does not function as an antagonist but rather as a positive allosteric modulator, meaning it increases the receptor’s response to GABA rather than competing for the same active site.
  • • (D) Propranolol – Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker (β-adrenergic antagonist) that blocks beta-1 and beta-2 adrenergic receptors, reducing heart rate and blood pressure. While propranolol is an antagonist, it acts more like a non-competitive or reversible antagonist depending on the situation, as it does not always allow for simple competition at the receptor level like naloxone does at opioid receptors.

questions.text: What is the term for the dose of a drug that produces a therapeutic effect in 50% of the population?
What type of drug interaction occurs when two drugs produce an effect greater than the sum of their individual effects?
Which of the following is an example of a first-pass effect?

options.label: B
options.text: Metabolism of oral drugs by the liver before reaching systemic circulation

options.label: C
options.text: Excretion of drugs by the kidneys

options.label: D
options.text: Distribution of drugs in body tissues

questions.correct_answer: B. Metabolism of oral drugs by the liver before reaching systemic circulation

questions.text: Which phase of a clinical trial is primarily concerned with the assessment of the drug’s efficacy and side effects in a larger patient population?
In pharmacodynamics, what does the term "agonist" refer to?

options.label: A
options.text: A drug that blocks a receptor

options.label: B
options.text: A drug that enhances the effect of an endogenous substance

options.label: C
options.text: A drug that has no effect on a receptor

options.label: D
options.text: A drug that initiates a biological response upon binding to a receptor

questions.correct_answer: D. A drug that initiates a biological response upon binding to a receptor

questions.text: What is the term for an unexpected or abnormal reaction to a drug that is different from its intended effect?
Which of the following statements about pharmacokinetics is true?

options.label: A
options.text: It refers to the study of drug effects on the body

options.label: B
options.text: It includes absorption, distribution, metabolism, and excretion of drugs

options.label: C
options.text: It solely focuses on the therapeutic effects of drugs

options.label: D
options.text: It is the study of how drugs bind to their receptors

questions.correct_answer: B. It includes absorption, distribution, metabolism, and excretion of drugs

questions.text: Which of the following factors does NOT affect the bioavailability of a drug?
Which of the following adverse drug reactions is classified as a Type B reaction?
Which pharmacokinetic parameter is defined as the time it takes for the plasma concentration of a drug to reduce by half?
Which of the following factors can significantly decrease the bioavailability of an orally administered drug?
Which of the following statements about the therapeutic index (TI) is TRUE?

options.label: A
options.text: A higher TI indicates a greater risk of toxicity

options.label: B
options.text: TI is the ratio of the toxic dose to the effective dose

options.label: C
options.text: TI is always a fixed value for a given drug

options.label: D
options.text: A lower TI indicates a safer drug

questions.correct_answer: B. TI is the ratio of the toxic dose to the effective dose

questions.text: Which of the following factors significantly influences the bioavailability of a drug administered orally?

options.label: A
options.text: Drug solubility and stability in gastric fluid

options.label: B
options.text: The first-pass effect by the liver

questions.text: What type of drug interaction occurs when two drugs produce opposite effects on the same physiological function?
Which of the following is a common outcome measured in clinical trials?
What is the primary role of the Institutional Review Board (IRB) in clinical research?

options.label: A
options.text: To approve the marketing of drugs

options.label: B
options.text: To ensure the safety and ethical treatment of study participants

options.label: D
options.text: To monitor drug interactions in patients

questions.correct_answer: B. To ensure the safety and ethical treatment of study participants

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a pharmacokinetic interaction?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased effectiveness of an analgesic due to a sedative

options.label: B
options.text: Antagonism of drug action by another drug

options.label: C
options.text: Decreased absorption of one drug due to the presence of another

questions.correct_answer: C. Decreased absorption of one drug due to the presence of another

questions.text: What is desensitization in the context of receptor pharmacology?

options.label: A
options.text: The process by which a receptor becomes more sensitive to its ligand

options.label: B
options.text: The temporary loss of receptor responsiveness due to prolonged exposure to a ligand

options.label: C
options.text: The binding of an antagonist that prevents receptor activation

options.label: D
options.text: The upregulation of receptor expression in response to low ligand levels

questions.correct_answer: B. The temporary loss of receptor responsiveness due to prolonged exposure to a ligand
